Co'authored-by: Eric Wieser [eric-wieser](https://github.com/eric-wieser)

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

bors d+

maintainer merge
bors d+

bors d+

Thanks!

And similarly for all the others
```suggestion
theorem IsUnit.natCast_factorial_of_lt {n : â„•} (hn_fac : IsUnit ((n - 1)! : A))
```
I put everything inside the `IsUnit` namespace.

```suggestion
theorem IsUnit.natCast_factorial_of_le {n : â„•} (hn_fac : IsUnit (n ! : A))
```

```suggestion
theorem IsUnit.natCast_factorial_of_ratAlgebra [Algebra â„š A] (n : â„•) : IsUnit (n ! : A) := by
```

```suggestion
theorem IsUnit.natCast_factorial_of_charP  {n : â„•} (h : n < p) : IsUnit (n ! : A) := by
```
This lemma feels a bit unnatural; can we drop it and just keep the `le` version?
The condition `IsUnit ((n - 1)! : A)` shows up naturally in the theory of divided powers (see #22322, where we invoke this lemma 8 times), so I would like to keep both versions.
Is an nnrat algebra enough? Or maybe `CharZero`?
`CharZero` isn't enough, `Int` is a counterexample. As Maria-InÃ©s told me, there is no `Algebra NNRat A` instance for `Rat`-algebras, so that would be unpractical. But this variant could be added.

Let's at least prove one in terms of the other:

```suggestion
theorem natCast_factorial_of_le {n : â„•} (hn_fac : IsUnit (n ! : A))
    {m : â„•} (hmn : m â‰¤ n) : IsUnit (m ! : A) :=
  isUnit_of_dvd_unit (cast_dvd_cast (factorial_dvd_factorial hmn)) hn_fac

theorem natCast_factorial_of_lt {n : â„•} (hn_fac : IsUnit ((n - 1)! : A))
    {m : â„•} (hmn : m < n) : IsUnit (m ! : A) :=
  hn_fac.natCast_factorial_of_le <| le_sub_one_of_lt hmn
```

This is true without commutativity.  An ugly proof is
```lean
theorem natCast_factorial_of_le {n : â„•} (hn_fac : IsUnit (n ! : A))
    {m : â„•} (hmn : m â‰¤ n) : IsUnit (m ! : A) := by
  obtain âŸ¨k, rflâŸ© := exists_add_of_le hmn
  clear hmn
  induction k generalizing m with
  | zero => simpa using hn_fac
  | succ k ih =>
    rw [â† add_assoc, add_right_comm] at hn_fac
    have := ih hn_fac
    rw [Nat.factorial_succ, Nat.cast_mul, Nat.cast_commute _ _ |>.isUnit_mul_iff] at this
    exact this.2
```
though there might be a slicker trick by going through `Set.center`.

What about:
```
example {A : Type*} [Semiring A] {n : â„•} (hn_fac : IsUnit (n ! : A))
    {m : â„•} (hmn : m â‰¤ n) : IsUnit (m ! : A) := by
  obtain âŸ¨p, hpâŸ© := Nat.factorial_dvd_factorial hmn
  rw [isUnit_iff_exists] at hn_fac âŠ¢
  obtain âŸ¨a, ha, ha'âŸ© := hn_fac
  use a * p
  constructor
  Â· rw [Nat.commute_cast, â† mul_assoc, â† Nat.cast_mul, â† hp, ha]
  Â· rw [mul_assoc, â† Nat.cast_mul, mul_comm p, â† hp, ha']
```

Here's a version that works for both `Rat` and `NNRat`:
```lean
/-- If `A` is an algebra over a characteristic-zero (semi)field, then `n!` is a unit. -/
theorem natCast_factorial_of_algebra (K : Type*) [Semifield K] [CharZero K] [Algebra K A] (n : â„•) : IsUnit (n ! : A) := by
  suffices IsUnit (n ! : K) by
    simpa using this.map (algebraMap K A)
  simp [isUnit_iff_ne_zero, n.factorial_ne_zero]
```
But this requires `Semifield` (which for instance is not true for `Polynomial Rat`).
Sure it is, set `K := Rat`. My proposal is to replace callers of `natCast_factorial_of_ratAlgebra` with `natCast_factorial_of_algebra Rat`.
Ah, of course you are right, sorry (I had not read carefully).

This also generalizes to `Ring`
```suggestion
theorem natCast_factorial_of_charP  {n : â„•} (h : n < p) : IsUnit (n ! : A) := by
  induction n with
  | zero => simp
  | succ n ih =>
    rw [factorial_succ, cast_mul, Nat.cast_commute _ _ |>.isUnit_mul_iff]
    refine âŸ¨?_, ih (lt_trans (lt_add_one n) h)âŸ©
    have h1 := Int.cast_one (R := A)
    rw [â† cast_one, â† coprime_of_lt_prime (zero_lt_succ n) h (Fact.elim inferInstance),
      gcd_eq_gcd_ab, Int.cast_add] at h1
    simp only [succ_eq_add_one, Int.cast_mul, Int.cast_natCast, CharP.cast_eq_zero, zero_mul,
      zero_add] at h1
    have h2 :=  Nat.cast_commute _ _ |>.eq.symm.trans h1
    exact âŸ¨âŸ¨_, _, h1, h2âŸ©, rflâŸ©
```
though can perhaps be golfed.

```suggestion
This file contains lemmas providing sufficient conditions for the cast of `n!` to a
```

```suggestion
theorem natCast_factorial_of_charP {n : â„•} (h : n < p) : IsUnit (n ! : A) := by
```

Also, is this true as an `Iff`? If so it would be a good `simp` lemma.

```suggestion
    have h2 := Nat.cast_commute _ _ |>.eq.symm.trans h1
```

pullRequest.title: feat(Mathlib/Data/Nat/Factorial/NatCast): add `IsUnit` lemmas
